website_summaries.verdict: The gold standard of tubeless tire sealants, this option works well and seals most punctures quickly.
pros: Works very well, even in lower temperatures
Long-lasting, and easy to clean up
Can repair a 1/4" hole almost instantly
cons: This option is not as effective if you don't drive your vehicle (rotate the tires) every day
Can dry fairly quickly, particularly in high heat conditions, requiring reapplication

customer_reviews.title: Best Deal
customer_reviews.text: I've used this and I've used Orange Seal. Both are solid products. I give Stan's the edge because it's cheaper and it's a little bit easier to clean up. I live in thorn country. Those stupid little goat head thorns will ruin your life if you don't use sealant. Now that I'm tubeless I laugh in their faces. I can't tell you how many I have pulled out of my tires. Stan's has never failed to seal a thorn puncture for me. The 16-oz bottle is convenient and easy to use.
customer_reviews.author: Adam BTop Contributor: Cycling

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use
customer_reviews.text: Watch the YouTube videos on the best way to use this. This was so easy to use, one note clean the rim and install a new valve might as well because you have access anyway I installed a new valve because I could. I’m going to include instructions side of the bottle in my photos this might help
customer_reviews.author: Derrick J. Tempro

customer_reviews.title: and other scrubby trails in the Southern California foothills so I ask a lot of tires (maybe not as much as riding through thorns all the time) and I've been happy so far
customer_reviews.text: I realize it's called "No Tubes" but I injected my standard MTB tubes with Stan's because I saw other cyclists doing it, and whether I'm just lucky or it works... no flat tires yet! I ride rough MTB trails, fire roads, gravel, packed dirt, and single track, and other scrubby trails in the Southern California foothills so I ask a lot of tires (maybe not as much as riding through thorns all the time) and I've been happy so far.
customer_reviews.author: Prime Fanatic in SoCal

customer_reviews.title: brand new tire goes flat, this product does nothing to prevent it.
customer_reviews.text: Had a flat Had Bike shop install new tire New tire leaked air Purchased this. Added 100mL, shook it all about. Tire (Cont. X King 2.2) leaks air right through the sidewalls (!?) added more air, shook more repeat. Tire goes flat. no liquid escapes the tire, never stops the air leaks.
customer_reviews.author: Andy

customer_reviews.title: Squeezes Right Through Standard Ball Pump Needle
customer_reviews.text: Stan’s did the job! There were multiple puncture holes in my expensive AVP Wilson volleyball, and this fluid filled all gaps. I tried to use Slime before, but that fluid was way too thick for even a 14Gauge needle with syringe. I highly recommend this product for inflating punctured balls.
customer_reviews.author: ron

customer_reviews.title: Really seals!
customer_reviews.text: For anyone that cycles with tubeless tires, this is the best tire sealant on the market. I discovered this stuff from a brother in law, and have not used anything else since. You have to make sure that during summer months and after rolling over terrain that has thorns and stickers, that you refill your tires as it specifies to keep the tires inflated and hole free. 5 stars
customer_reviews.author: Phillip

customer_reviews.title: Works
customer_reviews.text: I avoided tubeless riding for years. I always got flats unless I used thick walled inner tubes with sealant. My friend bragged about NoTubes and I finally tried it. It was so easy to use and absolutely works. It's incredible. My tires were old and had many holes in them but they still sealed with NoTubes in them. After a ride I would find the sealant on the tread and sidewalls marking the many holes that existed. Still, the air pressure held. Great product.
customer_reviews.author: CautiousBuyer

customer_reviews.title: NoTubes Works Good
customer_reviews.text: After patching flats on my MTB for years, I decided to try tubeless. I replaced my rim strips with Gorilla Tape and injected the NoTubes in the valve stem. It is messy but it works. Since that time, about 1-1/2 years, I have had zero flats. I pump up my tires to about 40 PSI and then forget about them for a month or two. They will slowly leak down to about 30 PSI and then hold there for weeks. I do not plan to ever go back to tubes!
customer_reviews.author: 1yrloose

customer_reviews.title: Saves you time after setup, plus pays for it self over time
customer_reviews.text: At first I wondered if tubeless set up would be worth it, best choice ever, as many times I would have to change tube, Stans sealant has work flawless. Easy to set up tubeless, cost over time pays for it self, easily, not having to change tube every time you get a small pin hole or bite. It can get messy if you’re not cautious but easy to wipe up, sealant will coat inside of your wheel and tire, if you need to change tire for some reason. There are videos on YouTube on how to set up tubeless tires also how to maintain sealant in tire, and finally how to reinstall new or reuse same tire.
customer_reviews.author: IG: MarvinMarket

customer_reviews.title: OMG does this stuff work!
customer_reviews.text: I sliced the side of my 29er tire with a nice 3/4” gash. I’m not sure I did it, but probably due to running it with pressure too low. By rotating the bike until the side gash was down, I was able to slowly inflate it until the Stans filled in the slice enough to ride 6 miles back to the trailhead. So pro tip: Use gravity to let the Stans collect just where you need it. I’m was so relieved to not need to walk. Thanks Stans!
customer_reviews.author: Sam from Santa Monica

customer_reviews.title: MTB tire sealant
customer_reviews.text: I have been running Stan's for years in my tubless MTB tires. This stuff remains liquid for a long time, and does a good job of sealing up small to medium-sized holes in tubeless tires. I have replaced tires in the past due to tread wear/switching to another tire, and have found plugs of Stan's filling would-be leaks in the tires that I didn't even know were there. If your're running tubeless MTB tires, you need a sealant; you need Stan's.
customer_reviews.author: Matt

customer_reviews.title: Works great
customer_reviews.text: Been using this product with tubeless road tires for a few years and overall have been happy. I've only had one plug that sealant wouldn't seal at full pressure but sealed well enough at lower pressure to get home. Hole was large enough to require patch in order to continue to hold full pressure. A bit messy to clean up if spilled but using injector through valve stem makes installation a breeze. Product has given me no reason to try any other kind of sealant.
customer_reviews.author: DWells

customer_reviews.title: No more pinch flats
customer_reviews.text: I was frustrated by the amount of pinch flats I was getting with on tubed mountain bike tires. I went tubeless, used Stan's as the sealant. I haven't had one air-loss incident in six years since, and that is with both Stan's No Tubes rims and standard rims. I've also used Slime as sealant and I have noticed the Slime deteriorates somewhat over time, whereas the Stan's seems less affected by this.
customer_reviews.author: smh272

customer_reviews.title: must have for TUBELESS tires,
customer_reviews.text: Used this to seal up my 27.5 2.6 tires on my Specialized ENDURO. I had to use almost 4 oz per tire for the seal, but as always, it helps with the thorns and small pricks in the tires. It dries out over time, so just pull the valve stem, use a 50cc syringe and refill tires in the hot summer. saved my A$s a few times from walking MILES back. carry co2 cartriges also.
customer_reviews.author: RxDaily

customer_reviews.title: It will work, but there's better options out there for sure!
customer_reviews.text: If you're looking for bike tire sealant there's better out there. (I like orangeseal) Stans was the first to do it right and I think all of the MTBers out there have used it at one point or another. My issue is it's heavy, too thin and doesn't work super well with flexy tires.
customer_reviews.author: Crazy Ballz

customer_reviews.title: Still the best
customer_reviews.text: What else can you say? It's Stan's. It's the best tire sealant on the market. After 17 years at bike shops I've tried everything from more expensive competitors to homemade sealants and nothing works anywhere as well as Stan's. Truly one of the few cases where the original is still the best product and not just because it's the original... Because it is truly the best.
customer_reviews.author: drackett77

customer_reviews.title: Light viscosity
customer_reviews.text: Put in new tires Rear was fine but there is a constant weeping of sealant from front tire sidewalls Not much but I see bubbles of it every morning I followed instructions and shook it up very good Did rear tire first Pressure is holding but the sealant weeping is concerning
customer_reviews.author: lover of stuff

customer_reviews.title: Works as advertised
customer_reviews.text: Works to do what it was designed to do. What can I say more? Enough fluids for 4 tires, which is what I needed. Once I finish my tubeless conversion, I'll probably buy another bottle just to keep around for topping off in a few months.
customer_reviews.author: joseph c.

customer_reviews.title: No more flats!
customer_reviews.text: Works great! I recently went tubless and I’m loving this stuff. It was nice to see it seal the leaks around the tire bead immediately, it defiantly does it’s job well. I did make a huge mess with it and it may have stained the cement but that’s my fault beware of spills haha!
customer_reviews.author: Blake

customer_reviews.title: No frills, works great if done correctly.
customer_reviews.text: No problems at all with Stans. If done correctly, it works wonders when issues happen on the trail. Before injecting Stans, it helps to pre-air your tires to seat the beads. I seen people and even bike shops not beading the tires pre-hand and just end up with a big mess. As far as on the go, I have had zero issues with thorns, and pinch flats. Tires run lighter and because there is no tube, less friction between the tube and tire(cooler).
customer_reviews.author: ronabong

customer_reviews.title: Great Sealant
customer_reviews.text: I have had good luck with this product. I have had several puncture that sealed itself enough to get me home, and I never had to add additional air, one hole was pretty big too. With a plug kit I was able to fully repair the tire.
customer_reviews.author: william carter

customer_reviews.title: All mountain bikes need this! Put it IN YOUR TUBES! or go tubeless
customer_reviews.text: I’m using it with tubes, just pull the valve core and shoot it in with a syringe, sealed my leak right up! Now I’m not worried about thorns so much! All bike tires should have this in them! All mine will!
customer_reviews.author: Jennifer J.

customer_reviews.title: Great
customer_reviews.text: This stuff works as good as they say. I’ve used slime tubeless and this flows and seals much better in my experience. Slime seems to be slightly easier for cleanup with water, but that should not be a considering factor.
customer_reviews.author: Tanner Rockwell

customer_reviews.title: So far so good going tubeless
customer_reviews.text: Set up my first set of Tubeless rims/tires using stans and an injector. Was super easy once I managed to get the tires back on the rims after removing the tubes. I struggled with the tires so the pouring some in the side of the tire method probably would have resulted in a heck of a mess. 2oz in each tire seems to be holding up well. Have not really noticed any punctures yet to test it though.
customer_reviews.author: Alex Hilt

customer_reviews.title: Always back to this
customer_reviews.text: My husband has tried other brands over the years but always comes back to Stanz. It works great and stores well (others harden over time and become unusable). This stuff has saved him many times, especially when riding in thorny desert terrain where he comes home with tires full of spines and is still going.
customer_reviews.author: emrm

customer_reviews.title: I've seen it work in action
customer_reviews.text: I'd typically get a flat once a week from thorns on the trail. Haven't had a single tire failure in months now. I've even been riding and heard a puncture watched the tire spit out a small amount of sealant, the leak stopped and I kept riding. Perfect since the 27.5+ tires I'm using are extremely difficult to remove on the trail, this turns a 15 minute repair into an unnoticeable event.
customer_reviews.author: Rachael

customer_reviews.title: Stopped the leaking
customer_reviews.text: Bought used bike that had tubes in the tubeless rims. After new tires and valve stems and tape was still leaking air through spoke nipples. This solved the issue over night. Little expensive but air tight
customer_reviews.author: Martin

customer_reviews.title: never use a tube again
customer_reviews.text: Stans is the best product out there. Its lasts so much longer than the off brands of tire sealant. If you haven't gone tubeless, you should. I ride in the desert so this is a must. I have 3 bikes and one is a fat bike and this bottle lasts me a long time. It never fails and I only add more because...dang its been 6 months and I should probably reseal my tires.
customer_reviews.author: Emily Murray

customer_reviews.title: Great product
customer_reviews.text: I’ve used Stan’s for many years, it does what it says. The pkg arrived on time and the product was easy to put in the bike tire. Good product, seals tubes every tim.
customer_reviews.author: Eldee

customer_reviews.title: Very good stuff. There are many goat heads on some ...
customer_reviews.text: Very good stuff. There are many goat heads on some of the trails/roads that we ride on. Our tire repairs have been significantly reduced thanks to Stans Tire Sealant. Even tuffies aren't stopping the leaks. I would give one more star, but I do periodically have to air up a tire that has developed a slow leak after the bike has sat for a few days - so its not perfect.
customer_reviews.author: Carlson9

customer_reviews.title: just ok
customer_reviews.text: this is my first time going tubeless for the season and i've already had the sealant dry up twice in the tire. I don't see any leaks otherwise, but i expected to at least be good for 1 season. Other than that it seems to work, no puncture issues.
customer_reviews.author: Bryan

customer_reviews.title: good stuff and it's doing the job
customer_reviews.text: Works as I had hoped and sealed up the tire. Sure is a big fight trying to get the 27.5" bike tire to reseat but I guess that's to be expected. I'll research sealing options and maybe I missed a video. On the second tire I tried to break the bead only around the stem and then cut the tube to remove it. The hope was to keep as much of the bead seated as possible but the one side unseated anyway. I made sure to keep the other bead seated. Anyway, good stuff and it's doing the job.
customer_reviews.author: Goat Herder

customer_reviews.title: Works VERY well!
customer_reviews.text: Brand new tires on our riding mower, both fronts went flat due to puncturevine in just a few days. Put the sealer in and no more leaks! Immediately sealed up and have stayed fully inflated. Great product.
customer_reviews.author: Tod A. Guthrie

customer_reviews.title: The stuff you need for going tubeless
customer_reviews.text: I mean this stuff is the only option you should use. Why are you looking at reviews? Just buy it already. Spend less time on your phone and more time on the trails! Stay safe out there!
customer_reviews.author: KewlGadget

customer_reviews.title: Good stuff
customer_reviews.text: I live out in thorn country and my road bike with an inner tube wouod get constant puncturea. Finally fed up with this i decided to buy the sealant. Have not had a a flat since.
customer_reviews.author: Aleksey Johnson

customer_reviews.title: It performs beyond my expectations.
customer_reviews.text: The Stans NoTubes sealant works pretty well. I only get 1/3 as many flats as I use to. It's more messy inside the tire after drying out some than I like. I have to add more sealant sooner than I like. I plan to stick with it because it's better than many other products.
customer_reviews.author: Ed D.

customer_reviews.title: no burps
customer_reviews.text: Sealed up easily with a floor pump. Even on my rear tire which is technically not a tubeless tire (WTB Nano). Had to top up air after first night sitting at 30psi, then when i went to ride i dropped down to 18psi for riding at Highland. No burps and have not had to add air yet.
customer_reviews.author: Alex

customer_reviews.title: Great for tubeless setup
customer_reviews.text: Remember that you will also need an injector/syringe (about $11) to put the sealant in via the valve. You *could* put it in directly by un-beading the tire but usually this turns into a bloody mess when you try to re-pressure the tire to get it to bead.
customer_reviews.author: Boardhead

customer_reviews.title: This stuff works great! I commute 22 miles a day and put ...
customer_reviews.text: I bought this as a refill to the original 2oz bottle I purchased at REI. I use it to fill tubes, not tubeless tires. This stuff works great! I commute 22 miles a day and put this stuff to the test for sure. I've got a front tire with 4 goat head punctures and it's still going strong. I've got a rear tire that has had 2 goat heads and 3 staples. These were the heavy guage staples for a large stapler (how I picked up 3?). This tube is still working fine also.
customer_reviews.author: NVSparky

customer_reviews.title: It works just works.
customer_reviews.text: I use it in all our bikes. Even on wheels that aren't "tubeless compatible"( I increase the amount used by 50% and it can take a couple days of airing up the tires and rotating them to fully seal the tire.) I also put it in my spare tube that I carry on trails.
customer_reviews.author: Terry

customer_reviews.title: Does the job!
customer_reviews.text: I used this product on my gravel bike tires and it have saved me more than once of having to walk back home, not a thing you want to do when riding at night through the wilderness. Minimal loss of tire pressure.
customer_reviews.author: JC

customer_reviews.title: Inflatable Dinghy Repair
customer_reviews.text: I used this product to stop small leaks in an inflatable dinghy. It seemed effective, but not completely probably due to not having enough fluid I used 2 pints! Also trying to achieve full contact with all surfaces was difficult-not like a bike tire. Would have liked more technical info e.g. surface area covered per pint and drying time?? Is it still rolling around in the dinghy?
customer_reviews.author: Bird Guy

customer_reviews.title: Use in tubes
customer_reviews.text: I put this in my tubes. Works very well. Remove valve, inject stans into tube and put valve back in. All 6 of our bikes have this.
customer_reviews.author: Peter B.

customer_reviews.title: this is the best tubeless tire sealing system on the market
customer_reviews.text: In my experience, this is the best tubeless tire sealing system on the market. Love that the product comes with its own measuring cup. I live in Colorado and needed a sealer that was going to endure the rough terrain. I swapped my tube system out for the tubeless option a couple years back with some skepticism. After two years of use and many many rides logged, I don't think I'll ever use anything else. You can also find this sealant in a small one dose amount, but I would recommend getting this larger size as the value drastically increases. Highly recommend.
customer_reviews.author: Scott

customer_reviews.title: Holding air pressure so far
customer_reviews.text: Ok, I have had this sealant in my mountain bike tires for three weeks now and not one flat and the tires have not lost any air pressure. Very happy so far, now I am waiting to see if it holds air after removing goat head stickers :-)
customer_reviews.author: Steve R

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for the job.
customer_reviews.text: Works just fine. My god, what are ya supposed to say about tire sealant!? The color of red on the label is stunning. And I gave it five stars for the "stretch" category, whatever that means.
customer_reviews.author: Kodiak

customer_reviews.title: One of the Best Sealants for Tubeless Tires
customer_reviews.text: I typically rotate between using sealants by Stan's or Orange for my tubeless MTB tires. The only downside of Stan's are the "boogers" plus it's much more difficult to clean out. On the other hand, Orange cleans up much easier. IMHO, you can't go wrong with either brand.
customer_reviews.author: CColesJr

customer_reviews.title: If it works it works.
customer_reviews.text: A little messy since I poured it into my tire rather than going through the valve stem. So far so good. This bottle will last quite a while so it’s worth the cost.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Makes Tubeless Easy
customer_reviews.text: Allowed me to convert my 20 year old MTB Mavic wheels to tubeless without issue (used gorilla tape to seal the rim). It's been 4 months and the tires are holding air wonderfully.
customer_reviews.author: Charles N.

customer_reviews.title: simply the best
customer_reviews.text: i've tryed them all and this is the best so far rim leaks are common on the farm this works best we've found
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Doesn't seal punctures
customer_reviews.text: I filled 4 bicycle tires with this fluid. One of my tires was punctured by a screw on the road. The tire went flat and the fluid just leaked out of the hole.
customer_reviews.author: J. Castner

customer_reviews.title: Works well
customer_reviews.text: I was new to the tubeless tire movement so bought this product when learning to change my tubeless mountain bike tire. Works exactly as intended and a year later still the tire holds air as expected. I would recommend this product.
customer_reviews.author: Adrenaline Seeker

customer_reviews.title: Amazing
customer_reviews.text: This stuff is amazing. Slime doesn't even compare to the puncture protection and weight. Highly recommended.
customer_reviews.author: Ross Kline

customer_reviews.title: Highly recommended
customer_reviews.text: I completed my first ever tubeless conversion recently, on a set of 4" fat tires. The process is rather labor intensive, but straightforward. It took a couple of days for the sealant to seal well, but after it was all said and done, the tubeless conversion dropped 2 pounds per tire.
customer_reviews.author: wvoldguy

customer_reviews.title: This is the way to go
customer_reviews.text: I went tubeless this year with Stan's No-tube Rims and of course used Stan's sealant as well. Wow... my MTB feels much lighter and is certainly more responsive when turning, jumping, or rolling over stuff. The lower tire pressures that tubeless makes possible really smooth our the trail, increasing speed somewhat while improving traction. No more pinch flats either. Pressures hold pretty well... comparable to tubes in my experience. Great product... be sure to add a little sealant every 3 to 4 months.
customer_reviews.author: Jason D.

customer_reviews.title: Garbage, just blew my shoulder out.
customer_reviews.text: First of all, it took about an hour for this stuff to actually seal my tire to the rim after the second try. Then, a few weeks later only after about 6 rides I did the smallest jump and the tire completely came unsealed from the rim and I ate it face first into some asphalt. This stuff is some trash, as well as their valve stems.
customer_reviews.author: dorothy digiovannantonio

customer_reviews.title: Sealing tires and no flat
customer_reviews.text: My go to tire sealant, never used a different brand because it works.
customer_reviews.author: Jim Bob

customer_reviews.title: It works!
customer_reviews.text: Been using this many years. First time using it, a new tire got a cut while riding. Rolled the tire so the sealant came out and it immediately sealed it. Still using the same tire today! May invalidate warranties on some tires so check before using it. It will eventually dry out and leave a gummy residue in the tire.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Seals tires
customer_reviews.text: This is old product tested by thousands and thousands. It works! Pour 1 to 2 caps into the MTB tire, depending on the size. Refill every 3-6 months or when you will start loosing air pressure. Designed for tubeless setup. However you can also pour that to your inner tubes (if you will find a way) to make them sort of puncture resistant. Actually, they will still get punctured but with this sealant you wont care as the hole will be sealed instantly and you will be able to keep enjoying your ride.
customer_reviews.author: Radek

customer_reviews.title: Does not work!
customer_reviews.text: Did not seal any of the punctures my tube received which were around 2mm. DO NOT BUY!
customer_reviews.author: Oi m8

customer_reviews.title: NO CAP INCLUDED!!!
customer_reviews.text: NO CAP? This is dumb. How can I seal the bottle back up after I use a small portion of it? I searched the reviews for "cap" and it turns out others are receiving it without the cap as well... Stan's is a good product, everyone here probably knows that. It's the standard. But c'mon... Selling without a cap? No thanks.
customer_reviews.author: Daniel Helms

customer_reviews.title: Seals it up like it's supposed to.
customer_reviews.text: There's enough to lots of tires. No problems with this product. Make sure to get the syringe for injecting it into the tire.
customer_reviews.author: Baron Von Nobzez

customer_reviews.title: Stuff just works
customer_reviews.text: Stuff just works, I ride in Az desert where you cant go one trip with a tube not getting flat. When I replace tire from wear, it was amazing the amount if thorns I had in my tire and no flat.
customer_reviews.author: michael ramirez

customer_reviews.title: tire Sealant
customer_reviews.text: Only thing would be nice if they would have a better see through side window in-order to see how much sealant is left in the bottle. Besides that Stan's NoTubes Tire Sealant seems to be #1 go to product......
customer_reviews.author: Roger

customer_reviews.title: Cheaper than buying individual bottles
customer_reviews.text: Has been using individual bottles and found this to be cheaper. Sealant must be top off or replaced once a while. This is a good way to some some money.
customer_reviews.author: Sandy S

customer_reviews.title: It works.
customer_reviews.text: Follow the directions (shake it a lot), and this stuff works. Takes a bit to work it into the entire sidewall and bead area, but once it's done, it's done. Adding more when required is easier with the syringe so re seating the bead is not an issue. I don't carry tubes, tire levers or a pump anymore. This stuff works.
customer_reviews.author: Scott Shatalow

customer_reviews.title: Did not work
customer_reviews.text: I have plenty of milky liquid spraying out the valve stem every time I connect to add more air even when the valve stem is at the high point, but still leaking air over time.
customer_reviews.author: JT

customer_reviews.title: 300 miles later. Have your cake and your tubeless
customer_reviews.text: 300 miles of jumps, technicals, rock gardens, dirt, clay, roots, logs, sand, gravel, wood and dirt berms... no leaks, no flats, no burps. Solid.
customer_reviews.author: Wyatt Herbivore

customer_reviews.title: Nice clean sealant!
customer_reviews.text: Using this sealant on 700x28 Pirelli Velo tubeless tires. Good product. No question about it!
customer_reviews.author: JohnnyRem

customer_reviews.title: Had to use 4 times the recomended sealant in tubeless tires
customer_reviews.text: I still recommend using a thin tube put some sealant in that incase you get a puncture.
customer_reviews.author: G.Mac

customer_reviews.title: Does the job.
customer_reviews.text: Very east to remove from tire and rim when replacing or rotating tires. A proper sealant. I've read several positive reviews about its effective sealing effect. Don't leave home without 2 oz's in each tire.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Good stuff-highly recommend!
customer_reviews.text: I swear by this stuff! I put it in my tubes and I don’t have flats all season. In fact I didn’t have any issues on the Arizona trails. One day I rode my bike on the side of a roadway in a rough area and my bike tires were covered in nasty thorns. I made it home but it was time to change out my tubes after the season was over. Before I found this stuff I was changing my tubes after each ride. It can be a messy process getting the liquid in the tubes through the valve stems but once it’s in there you’re good to go.
customer_reviews.author: bdranger

customer_reviews.title: Simple sealant
customer_reviews.text: Simple sealant. Works well for my road tubeless setup. Have bought several times. Would but again.
customer_reviews.author: D. Martin

customer_reviews.title: Stick to the faithful stuff that works
customer_reviews.text: Great product! I went with muck off and immediately regretted it.
customer_reviews.author: Gs1

customer_reviews.title: It works, but monitor in hot temperatures.
customer_reviews.text: I'm on the fence when it comes to which sealant I prefer. Been using stan's on both of my mountain bikes and it works well, but it seems to dry up quick here in Vegas. I just put orange seal in my new rear tire yesterday to see if it work better in the heat. I may try and make my own as another alternative.
customer_reviews.author: B. V. Roberts

customer_reviews.title: Good stuff. Works for me.
customer_reviews.text: Same stuff you get at the store. Don't forget to put glitter in the mix cup so that it helps w clotting the puncture. If it does go, you will look fabulous with your flat! (Seriously, put glitter in your mix)
customer_reviews.author: Lester Bernum

customer_reviews.title: Works as expected
customer_reviews.text: Seems to work well. I rarely get flats. I have had two torn sidewalls that it would not seal but I blame the tire more for that, not the sealant.
customer_reviews.author: JP

customer_reviews.title: Seals up perfectly on my Stans Flow Ex rim, ...
customer_reviews.text: Seals up perfectly on my Stans Flow Ex rim, and also worked as described on a tubeless converted Sun Inferno 27 rim. On the Sun inferno rim, did notice the paint on the rim bead was starting to come off, I'm guessing from the sealant. Again, the Inferno rim is not tubeless specific so perhaps the anodizing or paint was designed for use with this type of sealant. Not a big deal for me, as the rim will probably be replaced after a season or two..
customer_reviews.author: dylanbike1

customer_reviews.title: Stan’s
customer_reviews.text: Works well, I only have a few rides on my dhr2 tires. But I’m sure this is quality based on research. My last tires had a bright blue sealant in them, and it worked amazing.
customer_reviews.author: andrew

customer_reviews.title: Stan's is awesome.
customer_reviews.text: The best commercially available tire sealant for bicycles. It seals small punctures instantly, and my tires have been tubeless for the entire lifetime of the tire. It doesn't seal large punctures without a tire patch, but once you throw on a patch, Stan's completes the seal.
customer_reviews.author: cpennington

customer_reviews.title: Best way to go tubeless
customer_reviews.text: Been using this sealant for two years with no problems.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Still the best value for mtb sealant
customer_reviews.text: Stan's has always been a great product for me to use while mountain biking. I have not had a flat since using stands with my tubeless setup on my fat bike. As always Amazon delivered right on time.
customer_reviews.author: Machinewaters

customer_reviews.title: Great stuff!
customer_reviews.text: Works just like it is supposed to and now that I am topped off my tire pressure is holding again. Might as well replace your valve stems while you are at it!
customer_reviews.author: JD

customer_reviews.title: Old stock?
customer_reviews.text: Found it to contain a lot of dried up fibers. The product was not fresh.
customer_reviews.author: Nora Velp

customer_reviews.title: Solid Product
customer_reviews.text: After some online research I settled for this tubeless sealant and thus far it has worked well. Good product at a fair price.
customer_reviews.author: demickey

customer_reviews.title: Sealed hole I didn't know was there!
customer_reviews.text: Went tubeless and found out my tire has a side wall hole that the sealant promptly sealed and has held pressure even after a 10mi bumpy downhill ride.
customer_reviews.author: carol

customer_reviews.title: Great stuff - but watch out for peeling paint
customer_reviews.text: This stuff works as advertised. I ride thru dirt paths which are filled with thorns. I have had one flat in a year since using Stans. I have at least a dozen throns in my wheels and they hold air perfectly! Before Stans no Tubes, I used the slime tubes and still got flats at least twice per month. You do have to know exactly what your'e doing when setting up your tubless tires and rims. Beware however, that this stuff will cause paint on some rims to start peeling on the inside.
customer_reviews.author: IP

customer_reviews.title: Do not purchase!
customer_reviews.text: Small puncture in tire did not seal! Stan’s squirted out like water! Do not buy this product! Zero stars!
customer_reviews.author: Mike Robinson

customer_reviews.title: This product is the best! I put a small amount in my ZForce ...
customer_reviews.text: This product is the best ! I put a small amount in my ZForce Zodiac pontoons and absolutely no leaks. The tubes are porous and has small leaks but this tire seal stopped all the leaks. Great for Zodiac's and any inflatable.
customer_reviews.author: SWAMP MAN

customer_reviews.title: Good Sealant, but wish an Injector were included for Presta Valves.
customer_reviews.text: The sealant is good quality. I'm giving it 4 stars because it would be very helpful if something was included to help inject the product into innertubes with Presta valves. As it was, I wasted some of the Stan's Sealant trying to get it into the tube.
customer_reviews.author: M. Uhrey

customer_reviews.title: The original and still the best
customer_reviews.text: I've tried many of the different tire sealants. I went to UST on my mtn bike when they very first came out, and my road bike is tubeless now too. This stuff is the best. It dries up pretty quickly here in the southwest desert, I need to add a fresh squirt about every 2 months.
customer_reviews.author: Kent S.

customer_reviews.title: Gets you home
customer_reviews.text: I put this in an inner tube and it still should work as a puncture is a puncture whether in a tire or tube. It will get you home but that is all. You will still be removing the tire and patching it. And cleaning up a latex mess if you wait to patch as it oozes out the puncture if given time. I purchased solid tires, amerityres, and have never had to patch again.
customer_reviews.author: MSvendsen

customer_reviews.title: This stuff is great and not messy
customer_reviews.text: This stuff is great and not messy. It actually works, it has kept many tires of mine that have small holes in them inflated until I finally wore them down, definitely helps get the most bang out of tires.
customer_reviews.author: Michael

customer_reviews.title: Tubeless
customer_reviews.text: This stuff wirked great just piured some in the wheel mounted and aired wheels and now running tubeless simple and quick.
customer_reviews.author: Lou

customer_reviews.title: Good value and performance
customer_reviews.text: Good product, has held up and worked. Meets expectations so far
customer_reviews.author: Matt Orosz

customer_reviews.title: Sealed up my tubeless tires
customer_reviews.text: I tried this before in a tube as flat protection. it clumps up after a while and you have a lump of dried latex in the tube that kind of throws it off balance. I used this for 2 tubeless wheelsets, a 'tubeless ready' set and a conversion. it was able to seal up both sets after a couple of minutes. not flats so far, 400-500 miles between the 2 sets
customer_reviews.author: JC

customer_reviews.title: Guidelines
customer_reviews.text: I got this for my first time doing tubeless tires and it worked fine and all but I didn’t really know what I was doing so it would’ve been nice to have a suggested guideline for amount to use.
customer_reviews.author: Cole

customer_reviews.title: Amazon, where’s my cap?!
customer_reviews.text: I’m sure the product is as good as ever but they sent it without a cap! Not using the whole thing at one time so I’m slightly annoyed😡
customer_reviews.author: Derek B. Boyer

customer_reviews.title: Great sealant  - Less worry and more riding.
customer_reviews.text: This stuff is awesome sealed a non-tubeless tire with about 20 holes, its been holding air for days even with aggressive riding. Have tried other brands and nothing really compares to Stans in my experience.
customer_reviews.author: l!m!t

customer_reviews.title: Exactly what I needed.
customer_reviews.text: Worked like a charm. Perfect for tire damage from cycling through goat-head stickers.
customer_reviews.author: R Cheney

product_meta.title: NoTubes Tire Sealant
product_meta.description: Stan's Tire Sealant will stay liquid in a mountain bike tire with a thin casing for two to seven months on average. Riding in arid climates or storing the bike in a hot area will require more frequent monitoring of sealant levels. Special anti-freeze agent.
feature_bullets: One pint will convert up to 8 tires
Use only 2 ounces for most bicycle tires
Seals punctures up to 1/4" (6.5mm) quickly,Stays liquid 2-7 months for long-lasting protection
Premium low-viscosity formula resists freezing to work in environments as cold as -30° F (-34° C)
Can be injected through valve stems with removable cores compatible with tubes and tubular tires

Average customer reviews has a small extra line on hover* https://omni-grok.amazon.com/xref/src/appgroup/websiteTemplates/retail/SoftlinesDetailPageAssets/udp-intl-lock/src/legacy.css?indexName=WebsiteTemplates#40*/.noUnderline a:hover {text-decoration: none;}
